groundtruth: In Phase 1 dose expansion cohorts, patients with Microsatellite Stable (MSS) CRC can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For H&N cancer, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For melanoma, they can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a BRAF inhibitor for patients with a BRAF mutation. For NSCLC, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a targeted therapy for patients with a mutation such as EGFR, ALK, KRAS, or RET. It's important to consider these criteria when enrolling patients in the dose expansion cohorts.

groundtruth:
Certainly! Here are the full study arms we have designed based on our discussion:

1. Experimental: Domiciliary CGA
   - Participant Group/Arm: Frail older adults over age 75 who are discharged from the Emergency Department and referred to the Community Specialist Team in Limerick.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention will consist of domiciliary Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA) including nursing, medical, and allied health assessment and intervention. The majority of this intervention will be delivered in the patient's own home, with a medical review at the hub for specialist geriatric medical expertise. A domiciliary visit within 24-48 hours of referral will be conducted by a team member who will act as the case coordinator. Referrals for domiciliary care will be made based on patient needs, with individualized interventions prescribed. This arm aims to assess the impact of providing CGA in a home-based setting, which may improve patient comfort, accessibility, and overall outcomes.

2. Active Comparator: Hub-based CGA
   - Participant Group/Arm: Frail older adults over age 75 who are discharged from the Emergency Department and referred to the Community Specialist Team in Limerick.
   - Intervention/Treatment: CGA as defined above will be delivered in an Out-patient setting at the hub. This arm serves as the comparison group to the experimental arm, allowing for the evaluation of the effectiveness of domiciliary CGA compared to hub-based CGA. It is necessary to have this arm to assess whether the setting of CGA delivery impacts clinical and process outcomes among older adults.

Inclusion criteria: Clinical or pathological confirmation of the diagnosis of B-NHL at any risk group according to the Rai staging system. Previously untreated B-cell NHL: - High-grade lymphoma according to the modified Durie-Salmon grading system. - Stage 1 or 2 NHLSF/EORTC according to the International Prognostic Index (IPI). - Measurable disease according to the REAL score. - Lymphocyte doubling time > 1.5 months as measured from a single previous remission assessment. - Performance status (PS) 0 or 1. Previously treated B-cell NHL: - Relapse at any site after any number of previous therapies for B-cell NHL irrespective of duration of remission and type of treatment including transplantation. - Lymphocyte doubling time > 1.5 months. - PS 0 or 1. Exclusion criteria: - No prior stem cell transplant. - Severe comorbidity as defined by the following criteria: - Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status greater than 3. - Any grade III to IV toxicity after previous treatment. - Major or frequent (grade II) cardiac, pulmonary, or liver disease. - Known active CNS disease or a history of CNS disease with evidence of uncontrolled CNS prophylaxis. - Known active endocrine disease: Diabetes mellitus, thyroid disease, or severe psoriasis. - Serious bleeding. - Female patients not wishing to take oral contraceptives. - Inability to understand or comply with the study procedures. - Major gastrointestinal ulceration. - Active, uncontrolled infections. - Pregnant or breastfeeding women. - Any other disease or condition the investigator considers to be likely to prevent compliance with the trial procedures or that might impair the interpretation of the study results. Exclusion of previous trial treatment in previous NHL: - Documented evidence of relapse after previous treatment for CLL, low-grade NHL or small lymphocytic lymphoma. - Known positive test for HIV. - Sensitive or active autoimmune disorders.

Non-randomized intervention model: In this model, the participants will be assigned to the treatment group by a predetermined plan. In this case, will the treatment group be assigned based on a random draw from a hat or a computer-generated randomization scheme? Open-label design: Will the participants know the group assignment? Or will they be blinded to their group assignment? Masking: Has the study been masked or unmasked? Masking is the process of concealing the participant's group assignment from the investigators and sponsor, in order to prevent awareness of group assignment from potentially influencing the outcome. Masking is used in blinded studies. Please let me know if you would like details about masking, or if you have any other questions about these concepts.

Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Based on the details you've shared, I would suggest designing a single study arm for your trial. This arm can be named "Experimental: finite arm." The participant group/arm would undergo the procedure of Zygomaticomaxillary fracture repair. We would start by using a cone beam CT scan to create a 3D scanned image of the Zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture. These 3D images will be introduced to finite element (FA) software to evaluate stresses, micromotion, and life time for each model. The analysis will help us determine the best point of fixation for the fracture. After applying this point of fixation on the patient, we would perform another round of finite element analysis to verify the results. This arm will provide valuable insights into the role of finite element analysis in selecting the optimal point of fixation for Zygomaticomaxillary complex fractures.

model_response: The study design is a phase 1b/2 clinical trial. Phase 1b trials typically test a new agent in a small number of people to determine what dose is safe and tolerable. Phase 2 trials test a new agent in a bigger group of people to determine if it is effective in treating the disease. A phase 2 trial like the one described uses a control group to compare the safety and effectiveness of the new agent with the standard treatment for the disease. For this trial, the control arm is standard of care for patients with metastatic uveal melanoma, which is a combination of intravenous (IV) fluids and intravitreal (into the eye) chemotherapy for patients with evidence of central nervous system and/or liver metastasis. We also have a group of participants receiving the combination of Ziv-Aflibercept and Cemiplimab, which is the investigational arm.
This study design was chosen to maximize drug exposure while using the least number of injections and infusions.

The design of the experimental arm with the combination of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept was chosen for several reasons. Firstly, the combination therapy allows us to target multiple pathways involved in tumor growth and immune evasion, potentially leading to a more potent anti-tumor effect. Secondly, the treatment schedule and dosing regimen were designed to optimize the benefits of both drugs while minimizing the risk of toxicity. Regular monitoring of organ and marrow function, as well as echocardiogram assessments, will ensure participant safety throughout the trial.

Intervention Details:
- Ziv-Aflibercept is an investigational or experimental anti-cancer agent that inactivates vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) from functioning. It has been shown to prevent the formation of new blood vessels in tumors and inhibit tumor growth. Blocking VEGF may also enhance the immune response against cancer.
- Cemiplimab is a human monoclonal anti-PD-1 antibody that works by blocking the programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor on immune cells. This helps enhance the immune response against cancer cells.

Okay, based on the information you've provided, I have some suggestions for the design of your study arms. For the active comparator arm, I recommend using the Hot EMR technique. This involves an initial submucosal injection of physiological solution and methylene blue, followed by 'piece-meal' resection using a 10 or 15 millimeter diathermic snare and ablation of the margins with the snare tip. This arm will serve as a comparison to evaluate the conventional hot EMR technique.

For the experimental arm, I suggest using the Cold EMR technique. This involves an initial submucosal injection of physiological solution and methylene blue, followed by 'piece-meal' resection using a dedicated cold snare. This technique is hypothesized to have advantages such as reduced thermal injury and potentially lower recurrence rates. By comparing this arm to the hot EMR arm, you can determine if the cold EMR technique is a feasible alternative for large colonic adenomas.

During this session, they will review the movie version of the PREPARE program, including a new PSH-specific video and PREPARE easy-to-read advance directives with the new PSH-specific content and cover letters. The group facilitators will adhere to standardized scripts and protocols to engage participants in ACP through group sessions.

The second study arm is called "Facilitated one-on-one ACP visits." Participants in this arm will also attend a one-time 90-minute ACP session, but in a one-on-one setting with a facilitator. They will review the movie version of the PREPARE program, along with the new PSH-specific video and PREPARE easy-to-read advance directives. The facilitator will adhere to scripts and protocols to engage participants in advance care planning, tailoring the session to their unique circumstances.

The final step in protocol development is to determine the sample size. For this, we will use the primary outcome variable, which in this case is VAS pain score. We will use an α of 0.05 and a power of 0.8 to perform the calculation. Based on our literature review findings, we expect to see a 30% decrease in pain score with the Hypervolt Device. A priori, we expect a standard deviation (SD) of 15 points for the endpoint pain score, which implies a minimum of 80% of patients (n=25) per group will be needed to detect a difference (with 80% power) in pain score of 30 points between the groups (assuming a normal distribution of data). Dividing 80% by 2 arms yields 40 per group. Thus, our final study enrollment numbers will be 80 patients total, with 40 per arm. This may seem like a large sample size, but we must remember that this is a novel intervention and a large number of patients is needed to ensure sufficient power to detect a clinically meaningful effect. We must also consider whether the treatment effect is likely to be skewed (i.e., biased toward a particular direction). In any case, the final part of protocol development is to submit the complete study plan to the institutional review board (IRB) for approval.  If the IRB approves the protocol, we are ready to move on to the clinical study itself.

The level of pain in the area where the subcutaneous injection was applied will be evaluated with the VAS.

1. Experimental: Cohort A - In this study arm, patients with high and undetermined risk of fibrosis (bf+) will receive adaptive breast cancer radiotherapy using ETHOS. The intervention for this arm is Treatment ETHOS radiotherapy.

2. Active Comparator: Cohort B - In this study arm, patients with low risk of fibrosis (bf-) will receive conventional intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT). The intervention for this arm is Conventional IMRT.

These study arms will allow us to compare the outcomes of adaptive radiotherapy with ETHOS in high-risk patients (Cohort A) to conventional IMRT in low-risk patients (Cohort B). By assessing the efficacy and safety of adaptive radiotherapy in hypersensitive patients with high locoregional risk breast cancer, we can evaluate the potential benefits of personalized treatment and determine its impact on locoregional control and toxicity outcomes.

In Cohort A, the target volume for adaptive radiotherapy using ETHOS (Treatment ETHOS radiotherapy) is defined as PTV = CTV + 2 mm (except for IMC with 5mm), excluding 5mm beneath the skin. On the other hand, in Cohort B, the target volume for conventional IMRT is defined as PTV = CTV + 7mm, excluding 5mm beneath the skin. These target volume differences are designed to accommodate the specific needs of each treatment modality and the risk profiles of the patients in each cohort.

The first arm will be the active comparator for the adaptive phenotypes, where participants will receive the study drug. The second arm will be the experimental group for the maladaptive phenotypes, also receiving the study drug. The third arm will be the placebo comparator for the adaptive phenotypes, and the fourth arm will be the placebo comparator for the maladaptive phenotypes. Does this sound good to you?

Certainly! Let's start with the active comparator for the adaptive phenotypes. This group will consist of the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups. Participants will be administered Dupilumab (Dupixent), an interleukin-4 receptor alpha antagonist. They will also be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The goal is to evaluate the efficacy of Dupilumab in individuals with adaptive phenotypes.

The experimental group for maladaptive phenotypes will also be divided into Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. Participants in this group will receive Dupilumab (Dupixent) and undergo exposure to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The purpose is to assess the effectiveness of Dupilumab in individuals with maladaptive phenotypes and compare the treatment response between adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes.

The placebo comparator arms will mirror the adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes. Participants in the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups will receive an inert placebo instead of the active drug but will still be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The same applies to the Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. These arms are important for establishing a baseline response in adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes when not receiving the active drug.

As the participant improves, the therapist will gradually reduce the assistance provided until the participant reaches a point where they no longer require assistance or reach a plateau. The length of the study should be long enough to detect a difference in knowledge and beliefs, but not too long that it becomes excessively burdensome to schools and students.  A good duration might be two weeks, three to six months.  The number of schools and students needed? At least six to eight matched pairs of schools, one receiving the education and the other not.  And, finally, how will the education be evaluated? It should be evaluated in several ways, including pre- vs. post-intervention, as well as between-arm (students receiving the intervention in School A versus students from School B who did not receive the intervention).  How should the outcomes be measured? Measures that you might consider include short- vs. long-term retention of knowledge, beliefs and skills; changes in reported pain tolerance and pain behavior, as well as other clinical and quality of life outcomes.  How will adverse events be identified or screened for?  In a study of this nature, there is always some risk of adverse events. For the control arm, the proposed arm name is "Control: Sham tDCS".
In fact, we could also suggest "Active: Sham tDCS" although sham tDCS was not shown to have any effects in the studies you cited in the question. But considering the simplicity of name "Sham tDCS", the rarity of name "Control: Active tDCS" and the logical connotation that nothing happens in this arm the sham tDCS may be the best option.
The main consideration for the control group is to reduce the placebo effect. Using a placebo tDCS is difficult to justify at the moment due to the non-invasiveness of tDCS and its potential side effects including headache. Using a placebo device is not something that would have ever made it through a regulatory agency. Using a sham procedure reduces the impact of the placebo effect. Although sham tDCS had not been demonstrated to have any effect in the clinical trials of tDCS you cited, sham tDCS has been frequently used in the research up to now and has not been shown to have any effect in those studies. Additionally, there are a number of studies have shown the benefits of sham treatment in other conditions.
Together, the two groups, active tDCS and sham tDCS, create a well-balanced arm for efficacy and safety.

    - Ankle-Brachial Index: Measure the ankle-brachial index to assess peripheral artery blood flow.

By including a placebo group, we can evaluate if the symptoms improved by 608 actually represent a treatment effect or are due to placebo effects. 6.5 RATIONALE FOR DOSE Finding the optimal dose of a drug for use in clinical studies requires clinical experience and a thorough understanding of how drugs are absorbed, metabolized, and eliminated by the body. Phase I pharmacokinetic studies can be done early in the discovery process before large scale drug development begins. Dose-A pharmacokinetic studies are useful for determining the dose and route of administration of a new drug in order to reach therapeutic plasma levels consistent with efficacy. The objective of a Phase I dose-a, pharmacokinetic study is to achieve measurable drug plasma concentrations against which dose-efficacy relationships can be established in subsequent nonclinical or clinical studies. It is typically used when only a preliminary formulation is available and a final formulation requires optimization. To be considered effective, a new drug must have adequate bioavailability and its maximum plasma concentration (Cmax) must be greater than the minimum effective concentration (Cm). Bioavailability can be increased by decreasing its rate of absorption or increasing its volume of distribution. A sufficient dose for human Phase 1 use is that which results in a concentration that is 2- to 10-fold higher than the human equivalent of the optimal dose for a particular species used for preclinical testing. Maximum plasma concentration (Cmax) must be at least 30% higher than that seen with the minimum effective dose. Dose-a studies help determine whether: Increasing the dose of a drug increases or decreases the concentration of the drug in the bloodstream Increasing the size of a drug particle increases or decreases the drug concentration in the bloodstream Changing the formulation of a drug (e.g. tablet to injectable formulation) decreases or increases the concentration in the blood If the drug is absorbed slowly from the gastrointestinal tract, it is advantage

Let's review the elements of a well-designed clinical trial:
The main aim of the study
The inclusion and exclusion criteria to ensure eligibility of the participants
The experimental and control arms
The description of the interventions
The blinding of the treatment arms so that the participants and/or investigators are unaware of the treatment status of the patients.
With this information, a clinician can easily design a good clinical trial. The training is based on the Virtual Reality Aggression Prevention Training (VRAPT) protocol developed by Klein Tuente et al.    - Participant Group/Arm: Participants assigned to the Care as Usual group will receive standard care provided in the prison setting.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Care as Usual (CAU) in prison consists of treatments aimed at stabilizing psychological states, such as pharmacological treatment, supportive contact, or transfer to a Penitentiary Psychiatric Centre for necessary interventions.

By including a group that receives standard care practices in the prison environment, researchers can evaluate the additional benefits of the VR-TRAC program in reducing aggression beyond what is typically provided. Of course. In the first arm, the intervention is the Rex implants with a machined transcortical portion and bone consumption and expansion procedures. In the second arm, the intervention is the Rex implants with a roughened transcortical portion and the same bone consumption and expansion procedures.

Yes, of course. Both study arms will receive Rex implants with a machined transcortical portion. For the bone consumption procedure, we will use a high-speed tapping technique. This has been shown to be a safe and predictable method for removing bone in preparation for implant placement. In the bone expansion procedure, we will use a high-speed surgical drill to create a channel in the edentulous bone and insert the implant at a specific angle and torque. The roughened surface of the implant will help it to better integrate with the bone, resulting in a stronger attachment and a more natural look and feel. The comparison between the two treatment modalities will help us determine which results in better clinical and radiographic outcomes.

Certainly. The control arm will receive treatment as usual, which will consist of the placement of implants and prosthetic abutments and loading with a provisional prosthesis or temporary restoration. The experimental arm will receive treatment as in the control arm but will receive Ridge Expansion and Apex Reduction with either a machined transcortical or roughened transcortical surface. The machined transcortical surface will be tested to see if micro-machining of the implant shaft has an effect on clinical and radiological predictability of the implant in narrow ridges. The roughened surface group will be tested to determine the effect of a roughened surface for the narrow ridge application in order to test if surface texturing of the implant increases implant osseointegration for narrow ridges.  After placement of the implants, patients will be followed-up at regular intervals for a period of at least one year post-operatively, at which time radiographs and clinical photos will be taken and measurements of bone and soft tissue levels at implant level will be taken. The radiographic data will be evaluated at the time of placement and at regular intervals post placement, at one, two and three months, and annually until the end of the one year follow-up period at which time the final radiographs and evaluation will be performed.

model_response: For those unfamiliar, a Phase 3 clinical trial is the final stage before a new drug or treatment is released for mass consumption. Phase 3 trials are typically large-scale, multi-center studies that collect a lot of information about the safety and effectiveness of the treatment in question, as well as the side effects that people may experience. In contrast, Phase 1 trials focus on safety, Phase 2 trials focus on how a treatment compares to the standard of care, and Phase 4 trials take place after the drug or treatment has been approved and looks at ways to improve it. How to Conduct a Case Series with Qualitative Comparators
A case series is a type of observational study where a small number of patients are followed over a short period of time. The investigators in this case study plan to compare the patient outcomes of only two groups: the group taking the intervention and the group not taking the intervention. Here's an example of how such a case series can be structured.
Research Question: Do patients with rheumatoid arthritis experience improved clinical outcomes when they receive high-intensity statin therapy after a knee replacement?
The researchers would like to conduct a case series following 10 patients with rheumatoid arthritis after a knee replacement to determine the impact of high-intensity statin therapy.
Theory of Mechanism (Why this is the case): The investigators believe that high-intensity statin therapy may improve clinical outcomes in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

1. Experimental: Total pulpotomy
   - Participant Group/Arm: Individuals with severe symptoms indicative of irreversible pulpitis in mature molar teeth.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Complete removal of the coronal pulp tissue, achieving hemostasis with 2.5% sodium hypochlorite, placement of a 3 mm thick MTA material in the pulp chamber, closure of the pulp chamber with glass ionomer cement, and restoration with composite filling.

2. Active Comparator: Root canal treatment
   - Participant Group/Arm: Individuals with severe symptoms indicative of irreversible pulpitis in mature molar teeth.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Determining the working length, chemomechanical preparation using specific files, irrigation with NaOCl and EDTA, and filling the root canals with epoxy-resin-based sealer using lateral condensation technique.

Interferential therapy involves the use of two electrical currents of different frequencies and intensities being delivered to the affected area. These currents produce a pulsed, noxious, tingling sensation that activates the body's natural painkillers. Interferential therapy is thought to promote blood flow to the affected region, thereby accelerating tissue repair. Patients in the experimental group will receive interferential therapy on the affected knee.
Mulligan's mobilization technique consists of five components: log rolling, knee passive stretch, cross fiber, anterior glide, posterior glide, and compression.

The parameters for interferential therapy in the active comparator group are similar to that of the interventional arm, except for an increase in current intensity and a decrease in frequency. The current intensity should be set at the level where the subject feels a strong tingling sensation but not muscle contraction, and the treatment duration can be varied based on the needs of the patient. The sweep frequency should be set at 10 to 130 Hz.

Sure. The study design is as follows: Study Arm A: Mobilization with movement (MWM) - Maitland versus MWM + Interferential therapy (MWM + IFT) Study Arm B: Manipulation under anesthesia (MUA) - Maitland versus MUA + Interferential therapy (MUA + IFT) (Study Comparators: MWM, MUA)  The study consists of one within-subjects factor in which the two study arms (MWM, MUA) will be compared within the two comparator groups (MWM and MUA).  The study period of two weeks should be long enough for clinical and physiological changes following each intervention to take place. The study should be repeated by other investigators.
A randomized controlled trial in the effect of interferential therapy on outcomes of maitland (MWM) and manipulation under anesthesia (MUA) techniques on knee osteoarthritis patients.
One session per week for two weeks. Treatment will be performed by trained physical therapists.
Primary outcome measures assessed at 1 week (W0) and 2 weeks (W2) and include pain using a 11-point numeric rating scale (NRS 11); function assessed using a knee range of motion (ROM) and knee disability and osteoarthritis index (OAI).
Secondary measures of pain assessed at W0 and W2 include: - Visual analogue scale (VAS) for pain (0-100 mm) - Knee injury and osteoarthritis society (KOOS): pain (0-100) - Euroques questionnaire (EQ 5D-5L).  Secondary measures of function include: Quality of life measure as measure of health using KOOS; Tegner activity performance (TAP) and Timed up and go test (TUG) knee disability measures.

A randomized double blinded controlled clinical trial protocol design is as follows: 1. Seventy patients with the primary diagnosis of fibromyalgia will be recruited from outpatient department of the hospital. 2. After obtaining informed consent, patients will be randomly allocated in a 1:1 ratio into one of two groups: Experimental group and control group. 3. Experimental group will be administered the Pain Modulation Index test, followed by the Pain Detection and the Central Sensitivity Inventory questionnaires. Control group will be administered only the questionnaires. 4. Patients in both groups will have six weeks to complete assessments. 5. Patients will be contacted by phone one or two weeks after their final assessment to determine if they have experienced any changes in their pain. 6. Patients will be asked to complete the Visual Analog Scale to evaluate pain after two and four weeks. 7. Data will be analyzed using SPSS software, with a two tailed alpha set at 0.05 and a power set at 0.80. 8. In the case of an urgent need to discontinue treatment for any safety reason, patients in both groups will undergo treatment as guided by the treating physician. 9. The data collected from the two groups will be compared using the independent t-test or the Mann-Whitney test, and a p-value of less than 0.05 will be considered statistically significant. 10. The study coordinator will not be permitted to interpret the results or act as a potential reviewer. 11. The study will be submitted to the ethics committee of our hospital for approval. A copy of the submitted study protocol will be provided to the committee for their review. The trial will begin once approval is granted. 12. At the end of the study, results will be published in a peer-reviewed journal. 13. In the case of any unforeseen adverse events, the trial will be stopped immediately. Thank you for your assistance with this matter. I look forward to working with you.

Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Based on the details you've shared, I recommend the following study arms:

1. Active Comparator: Caries treatment
Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who undergo caries treatment only.
Intervention/Treatment: The patients in this group receive caries treatment, and the aerobic bacterial content in the dental office air is evaluated using the Koch sedimentation method. Microbiological analysis is conducted after the caries treatment.

2. Active Comparator: Caries treatment and fumigation
Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who undergo both caries treatment and fumigation.
Intervention/Treatment: Patients in this group receive caries treatment along with fumigation, and the aerobic bacterial content in the dental office air is evaluated using the Koch sedimentation method. Microbiological analysis is conducted after both the caries treatment and fumigation.

Please let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to make any changes to the study arms.

The first study arm serves as a control group to compare the bacterial levels in the dental office environment before and after any intervention (fumigation). By analyzing the bacterial content after caries treatment alone, we can assess the impact of fumigation specifically on bacterial reduction, independent of any other treatment effects.

The second study arm allows us to assess the combined impact of caries treatment and fumigation on bacterial levels in the dental office environment. By comparing the bacterial content before and after both interventions, we can determine if fumigation, in addition to caries treatment, leads to a significant reduction in bacterial levels. This arm helps evaluate the effectiveness of fumigation as an additional measure to reduce bacterial contamination in dental offices.

groundtruth:
Certainly! In Treatment plan I (PSCA CAR T-cells), patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer would undergo leukapheresis to collect their T cells. These T cells would then be modified in the laboratory to express the PSCA-specific CAR receptor. The modified T cells, known as PSCA-CAR T cells, would be infused into the patients intravenously up to 3 times during the study. Additionally, patients would undergo lymphodepletion therapy, bone scans, CT scans, tumor biopsies, and collection of blood, stool, and urine samples.

In Treatment plan II (PSCA CAR T-cells, radiation), patients would undergo the same interventions as in Treatment plan I, but with the addition of external beam radiation therapy. The radiation therapy would be administered in 2 doses and is intended to further target and destroy cancer cells. The rest of the procedures, including leukapheresis, lymphodepletion, imaging studies, and sample collection, would be the same as in Treatment plan I.

The rationale for this arm is to compare the outcomes of patients who receive embolization (Arms 2) with those who do not. By having a control group, we can determine the effectiveness of MMA embolization in reducing recurrence and improving outcomes.

The second study arm involves patients who undergo surgical treatment for their chronic subdural hematomas and then receive MMA embolization within 72 hours post-surgery. This arm will be referred to as Arm 2 - Surgery - MMA embolization.

The purpose of this arm is to assess the efficacy of embolization after surgery in reducing recurrence and improving outcomes. By comparing the outcomes of patients in this arm with those in Arm 1, we can evaluate the impact of MMA embolization on the progression of hematomas.

The third study arm involves patients who are excluded from surgery either due to significant medical contraindications or because they refuse surgery. Instead, they will undergo MMA embolization only. This arm will be referred to as Arm 3 - No surgery - Embolization accepted.

This arm is important to assess the efficacy of embolization as a standalone treatment option for chronic subdural hematomas when surgery is not feasible. By comparing the outcomes of patients in this arm with those in Arm 4, we can determine the potential benefits of embolization in these specific cases.
The fourth study arm involves patients who are also excluded from surgery but refuse embolization as well. This arm will be referred to as Arm 4 - No surgery - Embolization not accepted.

This arm is necessary to evaluate the impact of not undergoing any intervention in cases where both surgery and embolization are not accepted. By having this arm, we can understand the natural progression of chronic subdural hematomas in patients who do not receive any treatment.

I'm glad you agree. Now, let's summarize the full study arms we've designed:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Early cessation of sedation and TTM
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who will undergo early cessation of sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) after a cardiac arrest with a favorable EEG pattern.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention involves stopping sedation and TTM early, within 12 hours of identifying a favorable EEG pattern, and potentially weaning from mechanical ventilation if appropriate.
   - Reasoning: This arm is essential to assess the feasibility and safety of early weaning from ICU treatment in patients with a favorable EEG pattern. By comparing outcomes in this group to the standard care group, the study can determine if early cessation of sedation and TTM is a viable option for these patients.

2. No Intervention: Standard Care
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm consists of patients who will receive standard care, including sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) for at least 24-48 hours post-cardiac arrest.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The control group will not undergo early cessation of sedation and TTM, as per standard care protocols.
   - Reasoning: This arm serves as a comparison group to evaluate the impact of early cessation of sedation and TTM in the experimental group. By having a control group receiving standard care, the study can determine if the experimental intervention leads to better outcomes compared to the standard approach. This arm helps establish the baseline for comparison and provides valuable insights into the potential benefits of early weaning from ICU treatment.

For the sake of clarity in statistical interpretation, the target sample size is 68 per treatment arm as this provides 80% power to detect a significant difference between SVS20 and BUFY01 at the .05 alpha level with a 5% loss to follow-up and a standard deviation of the difference in effectiveness from the active comparator of .56 - based upon the primary endpoint success rate of BIASCIS on the KCS. This protocol outlines a study to assess the efficacy of a physical exercise intervention for improving pathologic complete response rates in patients receiving neoadjuvant chemotherapy for early breast cancer.

Ovarian cancer is a type of cancer that starts from the cells on the surface of the ovary. It is the fifth most common cancer among women, and it is often difficult to detect in its early stages. Treatment options for ovarian cancer include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, or a combination of these treatments. However, in some cases, there may be residual cancer cells remaining after treatment. A second look laparoscopy is a procedure used to examine the pelvis using a laparoscope (a thin, lighted tube with an attached camera) to inspect the pelvic organs. This can help detect any remaining cancer cells and guide treatment decisions. In this case, the second look laparoscopy may allow the physician to determine if additional chemotherapy is necessary, or if observation or maintenance therapy is sufficient.

With our study arms designed, and inclusion and exclusion criteria defined, we are ready to move on to the next phase of the mock study, the analysis plan.
Designing the Analysis Plan ↑
After defining the study arms and inclusion and exclusion criteria in the previous section, we can move on to designing the analysis plan, or study protocol, for the mock study. The analysis plan is an important part of the study protocol, as it describes how we will actually analyze the data collected. In clinical research, the analysis plan is usually broken down into several stages, each with its own protocol.
The analysis plan should address the research question being asked, how the data will be analyzed to answer the research question, and what outcomes will be compared to determine the answer. For example, in our mock study on participation rates in clinical trials by gender and age group, the analysis plan could include a statistical analysis of data from the included patients, broken down by gender and age group, to determine the difference in participation rates between each group. A confidence interval can be calculated to determine the precision and accuracy of the data, and statistics such as Pearson's chi-squared test or Student's t-test may be used to analyze the data. Based on the results, a conclusion can be drawn as to whether there are significant differences in participation rates by gender or age group. The full analysis plan should be outlined in detail in the study protocol.
It's important to remember that the analysis plan may change during the course of a study, as new information or challenges arise during data collection. It's also important to note that the study protocol should be thorough, comprehensive and clearly written, to ensure all research team members and external parties understand the protocol and plan of action.
Communicating the Results ↑
The final step in the mock study is to communicate the results to relevant stakeholders. Depending on the nature of the study, the results may be presented at a scientific conference, published in a peer-reviewed journal, or given to industry or governmental departments as part of a grant report. Presenting results in an academic setting may require an abstract, presentation, or poster, while publishing in a peer-reviewed journal will require a full manuscript. A grant

Great! The experimental arm will receive combination therapy of a PD1 inhibitor and short-course radiotherapy. Short-course radiotherapy is a radiation treatment with a course of high-dose radiation administered over a short period of time. It is hypothesized that this combination therapy will improve survival and decrease the risk of recurrence when compared to chemotherapy alone, as radiotherapy has been shown to be effective in shrinking tumors. The active comparator arm will receive chemotherapy alone. Chemotherapy, which is a combination of oxaliplatin and capecitabine, is an established standard of care for locally advanced colon cancer. This treatment is expected to produce the same outcome as historical controls in the same population.

In the active comparator arm, 60 patients will receive chemotherapy alone. The specific interventions will include CAPOX chemotherapy and PD-1 antibody. The rationale for this arm is to compare the efficacy of chemotherapy alone with the addition of an immunotherapy agent. Both arms will be followed up for 3 years, and the primary end point is overall survival.

In the experimental arm, a total of 60 patients will receive 5*5Gy short-course radiotherapy, followed by 4 cycles of CAPOX chemotherapy and PD-1 antibody. Finally, they will undergo surgery. The specific interventions in this arm include Serplulimab (300mg, d1, q3w), short-term radiotherapy (25Gy/5Fx), Oxaliplatin (130mg/m2 d1 q3w), and Capecitabine (1000mg/m2 d1-14 q3w). The rationale for this arm is to enhance the anti-tumor immune response and potentially improve outcomes for patients with locally advanced colon cancer.

In the active comparator arm, a total of 60 patients will receive 4 cycles of CAPOX chemotherapy and then undergo surgery. The interventions in this arm include Oxaliplatin (130mg/m2 d1 q3w) and Capecitabine (1000mg/m2 d1-14 q3w). This arm allows us to compare the efficacy of the experimental arm with standard chemotherapy alone, serving as the control group.

That's correct. The inclusion of short-course radiotherapy in the experimental arm aims to potentially shrink the tumor and improve the efficacy of subsequent treatments. Meanwhile, the addition of immunotherapy (PD-1 inhibitor) in the experimental arm aims to enhance the anti-tumor immune response. By comparing the outcomes of both arms, we can evaluate the additional benefit of adding short-course radiotherapy and immunotherapy in the treatment of locally advanced colon cancer.

Rationale, Objectives, and Design:
Title: A Pilot Study of the Gastrointestinal Tolerance and Safety of D-Allulose in Children Aged 6 to 8 Years
Study Design: Double-blinded, placebo-controlled, crossover trial
Study Population: Children aged 6 to 8 years
Timeframe: Four weeks
Objective: To investigate the gastrointestinal tolerance and safety of d-allulose in children aged 6 to 8 years
Study Population: Children aged 6 to 8 years with a Body Mass Index between 15th and 95th percentile
Intervention: Children will drink either 2.5 g of d-allulose per 120 ml of a fruit-flavored drink or high fructose corn syrup (control) for four weeks
Measurements: Symptoms of GI distress, blood glucose levels, and body weight
Exclusions: Children with a history of gastrointestinal disease, uncontrolled diabetes, or significant comorbidities.
Rationale: D-allulose is currently being studied as a diabetic sweetener that is metabolized in the liver unlike other saccharin substitutes such as fructose, sucrose, and sucralose which are metabolized in the gut. Its side effects to date have been limited, but more studies are necessary to fully evaluate its safety and tolerance in children.
Research Questions:
1. How does the gastrointestinal tolerance of d-allulose compare to high fructose corn syrup in children?
2. What are the clinically significant side effects of d-allulose in children?
3. What other clinical factors such as changes in body weight or blood glucose levels are affected by d-allulose consumption?

2. Comparative: Endocrine therapy only
Participants will receive only endocrine therapy without Ribociclib. The endocrine therapy options will be the same as in the experimental arm.

3. Control: Placebo
Participants will receive a placebo instead of Ribociclib, in addition to the same endocrine therapy options as in the experimental arm.

Patients in this group also receives Onivyde, Leucovorin, 5-FU, and placebo. This arm is to compare the outcomes of patients receiving the standard chemotherapy without Tripegfilgrastim."

Here, the Experimental arm is clearly identified as the arm receiving the novel intervention (Tripegfilgrastim), while the Control arm, which does not receive the novel intervention, is identified as a comparison to the experimental arm. The inclusion/exclusion criteria and target population are provided to further guide the establishment of the protocol, and the specific treatment regimen is included for each arm to ensure consistency in treatment across groups. By using consistent terminology and a consistent structure for both study arms, this example is easy to read and interpret for both novices and experts in the field.
In a crossover trial (where groups switch treatments), it is important to specify the sequence of treatment arms and which group is the control and which is the active arm in each phase. In this example, the first Phase is the treatment with the new treatment followed by a washout period, then the second phase is the standard treatment followed by a washout period, and then a cross-over to receive the alternative treatment. 
A within-subjects case-crossover example:
1. Experimental: Arm A
Phase 1: Treatment A
Phase 2: Washout
Phase 3: Treatment B
Phase 4: Washout
Phase 5: Treatment A
In this example, the order of treatments is important, as the first arm received Treatment A for four phases and then received washout, then the second arm received Treatment B for four phases and then received washout, before both receive Treatment A again. 


In an FDA example of labeling for multiple crossover trials, one trial used 120 mg Tegafur/Uracil for 4 weeks and then 800 mg Irinotecan (the standard of care) for 4 weeks with a 2 week washout before the next phase, and the the other trial used 800 mg Irinotecan first for 4 weeks followed by 120 mg Tegafur/Uracil for 4 weeks with a 2 week washout before the next phase. The FDA wanted to make it clear that this second trial was a crossover trial.
groundtruth: Certainly! Let's start with the Experimental Treatment Group. In this group, patients will receive a combination chemotherapy regimen consisting of Onivyde, Leucovorin, 5-FU, and Tripegfilgrastim. The chemotherapy will be administered every two weeks. Tripegfilgrastim will be administered 24 hours after completing the 5-FU infusion to reduce the risk of severe neutropenia. The inclusion of premedication and specific chemotherapy drugs is essential for the standardization of treatment across all participants in this arm. This arm is necessary to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Tripegfilgrastim in reducing the risk of severe neutropenia in patients with unresectable pancreaticobiliary cancers.

In the No Intervention Control Group, patients will receive the same combination chemotherapy regimen as the Experimental Treatment Group, but without the administration of Tripegfilgrastim. In the event of febrile neutropenia, Tripegfilgrastim will be administered after stopping 5-FU. Chemotherapy will be paused until the patient recovers from neutropenia, and then restarted after recovery. This arm is important to compare the outcomes of patients receiving standard chemotherapy without Tripegfilgrastim to those receiving Tripegfilgrastim in the treatment group. This will help determine the effectiveness of Tripegfilgrastim in reducing the risk of severe neutropenia in this patient population.

The following secondary endpoints will be assessed throughout the treatment phase: change of the following biomarkers measured by laboratory tests at the end of 6, 9, and 12 months of the treatment phase: fasting glucose, fasting insulin, fasting leptin, HbA1c, uric acid, serum creatinine, total IgA, lactalbumin, IgG, IgE, creatine kinase, ferritin, vitamin D, selenium, calcium, vitamin B12 and folate. The following endpoints will be assessed at the end of the treatment phase: stool fat and stool pH. The following endpoints will be assessed throughout the supplementation phase: stool amount and stool fat. The following endpoints will be assessed throughout the follow-up phase: stool fat amount and stool pH.

1. Participant Group/Arm: Patients undergoing primary debulking surgery (PDS)
Intervention/Treatment: Dynamic monitoring of ctDNA during and after chemotherapy
Reasoning: This arm focuses on patients undergoing PDS, as they are at a critical stage in their treatment journey. Monitoring ctDNA in this group can help detect minimal residual disease and predict recurrence, providing valuable information for clinical decision-making.

2. Participant Group/Arm: Patients undergoing interval debulking surgery (IDS)
Intervention/Treatment: Dynamic monitoring of ctDNA during and after chemotherapy
Reasoning: This arm targets patients undergoing IDS, who may have residual disease after initial treatment. Monitoring ctDNA in this group can help assess the response to chemotherapy and predict recurrence, guiding further treatment strategies.

3. Participant Group/Arm: Control group
Intervention/Treatment: Standard monitoring methods (e.g. CA125 levels)
Reasoning: Including a control group that receives standard monitoring methods allows for comparison with the ctDNA dynamic monitoring approach. This arm helps evaluate the effectiveness and superiority of ctDNA monitoring in predicting recurrence of ovarian cancer after primary treatments.

The IA + SSC Condition will involve all of the same prompts as the IA Condition, but with an additional prompt to write a letter of gratitude to someone who has provided meaningful support in the participant's life. Participants will be asked to describe how the supportive relationship has challenged gender stereotypes, and how these relationships have helped in their own acceptance of their gender identity. Participants will be asked to write the letter of gratitude within the week following the prompt, to ensure that any feelings of gratitude are still fresh.

In the control condition, participants will be asked to write responses about events of the day over 4 consecutive days, in line with the previous two conditions. However, they will not receive any prompts regarding internalized transphobia or gratitude.

groundtruth: For the TNB Identity Affirmation (IA) Condition, participants will receive the same prompt for all four days of writing. This design, often used in expressive writing interventions, allows for deeper and continued reflection into specific thoughts and emotions. The prompt will involve reading a vignette that describes the experience and response of a young adult who experiences rejection from a close friend after a first disclosure of their gender identity. Participants will then be asked to write in response to three prompts: 1) identify expressions of internalized transphobia in the vignette character, 2) reflect on times the participant has experienced similar feelings, 3) identify thoughts and feelings that promote and support a positive and affirming identity in contrast to negative emotions and thoughts.

In the IA + Strengthening Social Connections (SSC) Condition, participants will complete the TNB Identity Affirmation intervention on the first three days, following the same prompts as the previous arm. On the fourth day, participants will be directed to compose a brief letter of gratitude to an individual to whom they have not previously expressed gratitude, and who has provided meaningful and affirming support to them as a TNB person. This additional component aims to further enhance social connections and gratitude, which are important factors in promoting well-being.

In the Control Condition, participants will engage in expressive writing about events of the day, without any specific prompts related to TNB identity or social connections. This neutral writing task will serve as a comparison to evaluate the specific impact of the TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing internalized stigma and promoting well-being, compared to general expressive writing.

Exactly! You have successfully designed the study arms. These arms will allow us to assess the impact of TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing stigma and promoting well-being in TNB individuals. Well done!

   - Intervention/Treatment: Drug: Placebo drug
   - Rationale: The inclusion of a placebo group is essential to evaluate the efficacy of the experimental treatment (MTT) in comparison to a control group. By administering a placebo consisting of a mixture of trehalose and crystalline methylcellulose in capsules that are visually indistinguishable from the active product, the researchers can assess the true effects of MTT on HS patients. This arm helps to control for any placebo effects and provides a baseline for comparison with the experimental group.

model_response: Phase 4 trials are used to confirm the safety and efficacy of a treatment under investigation in a larger group of people. There are several different phases of clinical trials, which involve different numbers of people and different types of research questions. Some examples of different phases are: 1. Phase 1: Tests the safety of new procedures in a small group of people with a disease or condition. 2. Phase 2: Tests the effectiveness of a treatment in a larger group of people with a disease or condition. 3. Phase 3: Tests a treatment's effectiveness in a large group of people with a disease or condition compared to a standard treatment, or a placebo (sugar pill). 4. Phase 4: Studies a treatment in real-world settings after it is approved by a regulatory agency (such as the FDA). Can you provide more details about the population you're planning to recruit?

Absolutely! The design of the "Experimental: Peripheral airway biopsy arm" is reasonable and necessary for the goals of this trial. It aims to investigate the diagnostic yield of peripheral airway biopsy in detecting granulomas in patients with sarcoidosis. By specifically targeting the peripheral airways (>6th branching generation), which are not typically accessible with standard bronchoscopes, this arm seeks to determine if this approach can provide additional diagnostic information compared to biopsy of central airways. The use of forceps biopsy under direct endoscopic visualization ensures accurate sampling of the peripheral airways.

Rationale: Nocturnal continuous positive airway pressure therapy is the gold standard treatment for symptomatic OSA. It provides positive pressure via a nasal or oronasal mask to prevent upper airway collapse during sleep. This study arm is essential to assess the efficacy of CPAP therapy in treating obstructive sleep apnea. By initiating CPAP therapy and then withdrawing it for a short period, we can evaluate the acute and long-term effects of CPAP on physiological parameters in patients with moderate to severe OSA. This arm will provide valuable information on the impact of CPAP therapy withdrawal on OSA recurrence and the potential consequences of discontinuing treatment.

Certainly! The participant group/arm for the experimental arm will be named "Early Initiated Physiotherapy Intervention." This arm will involve all participants receiving the intervention, which is physical activity. The intervention will primarily focus on exercises that can improve venous return and will consist of progressive walking training at moderate and high intensity. Participants will also receive guidance on physical activity. The training program is inspired by the WHO's recommendations for physical activity. Initially, there will be a 14-day introductory period where the goal is to achieve 30 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity per day. After 14 days, the patient will receive physiotherapeutic guidance in physical activity and progress to the next period of 14 days, aiming for 2 sessions of 20 minutes of high-intensity physical activity per week. After one month of training, the patient will be guided on maintaining and possibly progressing physical activity. This arm will help us assess the value of early-initiated physiotherapy in improving outcomes for DVT patients.

Title: A Randomized, Multi-Center, Double-blind, Vehicle-Controlled, 2-arm parallel group study of the efficacy of DA-OTC-002 on the reduction of hair loss in females (Female Hair Loss Study).

[*]Purpose:

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of DA-OTC-002 compared to vehicle in subjects with female pattern hair loss.

[*]Objective:

The objective of this study is to evaluate the change in the rate of hair shedding (as measured by the Hair Shedding Assessment Card) from baseline to month 6 in the target treatment area of the scalp. The change will be analyzed to determine the efficacy of DA-OTC-002

[*]Study design:

This is a multicenter, randomized, vehicle-controlled, double-blind, 6-month, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy of DA-OTC-002 compared to vehicle in subjects with female pattern hair loss.

[*]Number of subjects at each center:

3 centers. Each center will enroll approximately 100 subjects.

[*]Subject eligibility:

Subjects will be considered eligible for the study if they have female pattern hair loss.

[*]Inclusion/Exclusion criteria:

Subjects will be included in the study if they

Are female
Are between 18-45 years old
Are able to comprehend the inclusion/exclusion criteria and informed consent
Have Fitzpatrick skin phototype I-VI
Have female pattern hair loss (requires an MHI [hair shedding] score of at least 60 [moderate] on the Kroger Hair Symptom and Severity Scale (KHSSS))
Are not pregnant or breast-feeding at the time of study entry.
Are willing and able to comply with the study procedures, including wearing of concealing wigs or hairpieces and refraining from the use of other

Now that you have settled on the general structure of the trial design, it is important to address some finer points.
For trials that involve the comparison of two active treatments, it is also important to consider the method of blinding and unblinding. A double-blind design is when the treatment assignment is hidden from both the participants and study staff, whereas a single-blind design involves blinding the participants but not the staff. For some trials, it may make sense to have a "crossover" design, in which the treatment assignment is concealed initially, and after a prespecified period, participants are allowed to know their assignment. There may be circumstances in which unblinding is appropriate--for example, if there are severe adverse effects or loss of efficacy of a treatment. It is also important to have a plan for how to deal with premature study terminations due to loss of blind. Once the CONSORT team has approved the trial design, they will provide feedback and ensure that the design is consistent with their recommendations.
Preparing the full protocol is an in-depth process that involves providing detailed descriptions of the objectives, inclusion/exclusion criteria, planned analysis plan, methods of randomization, data collection, reporting, and more. The protocol for a medical device trial is often several hundred pages in length. The NIH will require that the protocol be submitted as part of the FDA submission document as well. It is strongly recommended that the draft protocol be circulated to other experts in the field and subject matter experts to ensure it is comprehensive and written in a way that is clear and informative. Having a strong protocol is critical to obtaining FDA approval for the study.

This will be administered over the course of two hours upon determination that the patient is 10 cm in cervical dilation. The purpose of this arm is to evaluate the efficacy of caffeine and sodium benzoate in shortening the second stage of labor and augmenting pushing efforts.

In the placebo arm, nulliparous pregnant mothers at term will receive 500 cc normal saline, which will be administered over the course of two hours upon determination that the patient is 10 cm in cervical dilation. The purpose of this arm is to serve as a control group and compare the effects of caffeine and sodium benzoate with a placebo. This will help us assess the true impact of the intervention on the second stage of labor.

Absolutely! Let's go through the reasoning for each arm:

1. For Experimental: Phase 2 - Arm A, we want to assess the efficacy and safety of a higher dose of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab and chemotherapy. This will help determine the optimal dose of fianlimab for the treatment.

2. In Experimental: Phase 2 - Arm B, we aim to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a lower dose of fianlimab. This will allow us to determine if a lower dose is equally effective with fewer side effects.

3. Experimental: Phase 2 - Arm C serves as a control group to compare the efficacy of cemiplimab and chemotherapy with the addition of a placebo. By including a placebo, we can assess the specific contribution of fianlimab to the treatment outcomes.

4. Experimental: Phase 3 - Arm A or B is designed to confirm the efficacy and safety of the chosen dose of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab and chemotherapy. Offering two options for the dose of fianlimab allows us to assess which dose is more effective.

5. Finally, Experimental: Phase 3 - Arm C serves as another control group to evaluate the efficacy of cemiplimab and chemotherapy with the addition of a placebo. By including a placebo, we can determine the specific impact of fianlimab on the treatment outcomes.

Role of Statistical Analysis in Clinical Trials
In this activity, you reviewed the roles of inclusion and exclusion criteria in clinical studies. Can we do better than that? We hope so! We reviewed the sample size calculation formula in a previous module to determine how well an existing study design would recruit enough participants to answer the research question. Here, we are going to go a step further to ask if enough patients with the disease of interest will be included in this trial, and how we can improve the success of the study by minimizing the dropouts. In the context of clinical trials, we use statistical analysis to assess whether the difference in treatment effect between treatment groups (e.g., drug vs. placebo or competing drug) is statistically significant. The statistical analysis used is often a t-test or analysis of variance (ANOVA), and this is why they are referred to as clinical endpoints. In addition, the effect size or power of the study can also be determined using this analysis. For example, if the drug being studied has a large effect, and we want to see a large difference in drug treatments, we will need more subjects in each group to answer our research question. However, if the effect size of the drug is small, we might only need to recruit approximately half of the patients per group to get the answer. Therefore, we need to calculate the effect size or power of the study to know how much samples are needed. This is how statistical analysis is essential in a clinical study.

Designing a clinical trial can be a daunting task, and the inclusion and exclusion criteria are crucial elements that need careful consideration. This module will discuss how to develop inclusion and exclusion criteria as well as provide some examples.
For more information on how to register and report clinical trials, please see the "Clinical Trial Registration" and the "Conducting and Reporting a Clinical Trial "modules from this pathway.
Developing Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria
Inclusion and exclusion criteria help to ensure that studies produce reliable and valid results by enrolling only those subjects who are most likely to be affected by the medical condition or intervention of interest. In other words, the inclusion and exclusion criteria should be developed to identify the population that is most likely to benefit from the intervention being studied, and excluding those participants who would not be likely to benefit. Therefore, the inclusion and exclusion criteria need to be based on sound scientific rationale. The goals of the inclusion and exclusion criteria should be:
Identifying subjects who are likely to show a clinically meaningful response to the intervention being studied
Ensuring the results of the study are generalizable to the intended target population.
Inclusion and exclusion criteria are sometimes combined into a list that includes a number of criteria. For example, a study may require a positive history of symptoms for ≥2 months or symptoms that cause significant discomfort or interference with daily life. In this case, the list of criteria would include:
Positive history of plantar warts for ≥2 months
Symptoms that cause significant discomfort or interference with daily life.
Criteria that are important to consider when developing inclusion and exclusion criteria include the following:
Age: It is important to ensure that the risk of treating the disease or medical condition is not focused only on a specific age group.
Gender: It is important to ensure that the sample size of each gender is adequate to detect a difference, if one exists.
Potential drug and disease interactions: Certain drugs are contraindicated in certain populations; therefore, inclusion and exclusion criteria should be developed to ensure that subjects are on appropriate medications before enrollment.
Concurrent illnesses: Inclusion and exclusion criteria should not preclude participants with certain clinical conditions from participating in the study.

model_response: Sure thing! Part A would be the escalation arm, in which eligible participants are first administered Tepotinib alone. This is designed to help us establish a pharmacokinetic baseline of the drug in the participants' bodies. If a participant has promising responses, such as stable disease or even a complete response, they would be crossed over to the expansion arm, where they receive Tepotinib in combination with Pembrolizumab. The intention is to assess the safety and efficacy of the combination treatment. It's important to note that participants on the escalation arm will be removed from the study if they experience unacceptable toxicity or disease progression.

In Part B - Expansion, we will enroll patients who have received one or more lines of systemic anticancer therapy for advanced NSCLC. This arm will help us evaluate the efficacy of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab. We will first evaluate safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacogenomics at a lower dose. groundtruth: Absolutely. The second study arm, labeled as "Drug: Low BPV Regimen," focuses on implementing the low BPV regimen in participants who are in the highest decile of BPV. Each participant's physician will invite them to complete a 48-hour ABPM, followed by cross-titration from their current antihypertensive regimen to the low BPV regimen. The low BPV regimen consists of Amlodipine and Indapamide as the primary medications. I would suggest starting patients on Amlodipine 5mg daily, with uptitration to 10mg daily to achieve a goal systolic blood pressure (SBP) of less than 130 mmHg. Indapamide should be added at 1.25mg daily and increased to 2.5mg daily if needed to meet the target SBP. Other antihypertensive medications should be discontinued as the SBP target is reached. Patients not meeting the target SBP on maximally tolerated Amlodipine and Indapamide will be suggested to have a long-acting angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)/ angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) added to their therapy. After one week at the target SBP on the low-BPV regimen, patients will complete another 48-hour ABPM for evaluation of the change in BPV.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms for your clinical trial:

Participant Group/Arm: Other: Ambulatory Blood Pressure Monitor (ABPM)
Intervention/Treatment: Drug: Low BPV Regimen
Description: Participants on antihypertensive pharmacotherapy in the highest decile of BPV will undergo a 48-hour ABPM to determine baseline BPV. Subsequently, their primary care physicians will be guided through titrations to antihypertensive medications to a low BPV regimen. The optional sub-study will test the hypothesis that ABPM and SKNA data can be simultaneously captured and that BPV will be positively correlated with SKNA. Participants in the sub-study will be fitted with a single patch ECG for the analysis of SKNA.

Study Arm 2:
Participant Group/Arm: Drug: Low BPV Regimen
Intervention/Treatment: Each participant's physician will invite them to complete a 48-hour ABPM, followed by cross-titration from their current antihypertensive regimen to a low BPV regimen consisting of Amlodipine and Indapamide. Patients will be suggested to start with Amlodipine 5mg daily, with uptitration to 10mg daily to achieve a goal SBP of less than 130 mmHg. Indapamide will be suggested to be added at 1.25mg daily and increased to 2.5mg daily, if needed. Other antihypertensive medications will be discontinued as the SBP target is reached. Patients not meeting the target SBP on maximally tolerated Amlodipine and Indapamide will be suggested to have a long-acting ACE/ARB added to their therapy. After one week at the target SBP on the low-BPV regimen, patients will complete another 48-hour ABPM for evaluation of the change in BPV.

The intervention/treatment will be an observational study to observe the impact of digenic mutations on hearing loss over 4 years. This arm is crucial to understand the effects of digenic mutations on hearing loss, as this is a more complex genetic scenario compared to single gene mutations. By studying this group, we can gain insights into how multiple genetic factors interact to contribute to hearing loss in pediatric participants.

Study design: IRB approved, single-center, prospective, observational-comparative 3. P.I.: Smith, Yadav, MD 4. Setting: University of Florida, Gainesville 5. Study population: Patients with Crohn's disease who have a planned procedure for ileo-colonic resection 6. Inclusion/exclusion criteria: Diagnosis of Crohn's disease by clincal history, physical exam, and biopsy. No prior surgery or radiation therapy of the abdomen within the past year. 7. Intervention/risk/benefits/purpose: Patients will undergo standardized oral bowel preparation, an upper GI endoscopy, and a 75 mL normal saline load. For the control group, a standard duplex ultrasound will be performed. This is a pilot study to determine the feasibility of adding shear-wave elastography into the workflow for patients with Crohn's disease undergoing ileo-colonic resection. 8. Expected benefits: The ability to predict which patients with Crohn's disease may have significant fibrosis, which would require a formal evaluation before proceeding with ileo-colonic resection. The ability to identify which patients may be at risk of stricture formation after resection. 9. Number of subjects: 15 patients will be enrolled 10. Blinding: The control group will be blinded to the results of their ultrasound. The experimental group will not be blinded by the operator who performs the shear-wave elastography. 11. Thank you for the detailed information. Now, let's move on to designing the study arms. We have two study arms in this trial. The first study arm consists of patients with pT1 NMIBC who underwent a second TURBt. The intervention for this group is the second TURBt procedure, performed according to the current EAU Guidelines for pT1 NMIBC. The purpose of this arm is to assess the presence or absence of residual tumor at the time of the second TURBt. By studying this group, we can identify predictors of residual tumor and potentially select candidates for a risk-adapted strategy.

The second study arm includes patients with pT1 NMIBC who underwent a second TURBt within 6-8 weeks after a macroscopically completed first TURBt. Similar to the first study arm, the intervention for this group is the second TURBt procedure. The purpose of this arm is to evaluate the impact of the timing of the second TURBt on the presence of residual tumor. By comparing patients who undergo the second TURBt within a defined timeframe after the initial procedure, we can assess whether early repeat resection is associated with better outcomes in terms of residual tumor detection. This information can help us determine the optimal timing for the second TURBt in patients with pT1 NMIBC.

The participants will be responsible for calling the clinics to set up their appointments. The intervention entails the use of EUS to deliver a lumen-apposing metal stent (LAMS) for the treatment of benign gallbladder pathology, including cholelithiasis, chronic calculous cholecystitis, and cholecystitis. When needed, endoscopic lithotripsy will be used to fragment gallstones, which may inhibit stent-jumping and facilitate the procedure.  EUS-guided gallbladder manipulation by ultrasound imaging is minimally invasive, bloodless, and without the risks involved in laparoscopic or open surgery.  In addition, because no dissection of the gallbladder is needed during EUS or endoscopic lithotripsy, the risk of short and long-term complications are minimized.  Compared to laparoscopic cholectomy, EUS-guided therapy is technically simpler, with a shorter postoperative recovery period and in-hospital stay.   However, because of the learning curve associated with this emerging endoscopic technique, surgical intervention may not be feasible for the current pilot study and we must proceed with endoscopic therapy instead.  Endoscopic lithotripsy is a relatively new method used to fragment stones that cannot be safely removed by the stent, and its efficacy is unknown at this time.  This is the first EUS-guided gallbladder intervention performed in the United States.

First cholecystoscopy will be done 2 weeks after the index procedure.

The 6-minute walk distance evaluation will provide valuable information on the patient's physical fitness and endurance, which is important for assessing their overall health status and potential post-operative outcomes. Activity monitoring through an Actigraph will help researchers understand the patient's daily activity levels and patterns, which can impact their recovery and long-term success following sleeve gastrectomy. Continuous glucose monitoring is crucial for monitoring glucose levels in patients with renal failure, as they are at higher risk for metabolic complications. Blood pressure monitoring is essential for patients with renal failure, as hypertension is a common comorbidity. Body composition scan will provide detailed information on the patient's body composition, including fat percentage, muscle mass, and visceral fat, which are important factors to consider in the context of sleeve gastrectomy and renal failure. Mixed meal testing will assess the patient's metabolic response to a standardized meal, providing insights into their nutritional status and potential post-operative dietary considerations. Quality of life assessment is crucial for evaluating the impact of sleeve gastrectomy on the patient's overall well-being and satisfaction with the procedure.

Great! Here is the study arm design for patients with renal failure undergoing sleeve gastrectomy:
- Participant Group/Arm: Renal Failure Sleeve Gastrectomy
- Intervention/Treatment: 
   - Diagnostic Test: 6 minutes walk distance
      - Subjects walk as far as possible for 6 minutes at a self-selected pace, and the total distance walked will be recorded
   - Behavioral: Activity Monitor
      - Subjects will wear an Actigraph on their wrist like a watch for up to 10 days at home to monitor activity.
   - Behavioral: Continuous Glucose Monitor
      - Subjects will collect glucose values in the fluid under their skin for up to 10 days at home.
   - Behavioral: Blood Pressure Monitoring
      - Subjects will monitor their blood pressure at home for 10 consecutive days 3 times a day
   - Diagnostic Test: Blood Pressure Monitoring
      - 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring
   - Diagnostic Test: Body Composition Scan
      - Measure of body fat percentage, skeletal muscle mass, body water, and visceral fat.
   - Diagnostic Test: Mixed meal testing
      - Subjects will consume 6 ml/kg body weight of Boost, up to a maximum of 360 ml, within 5 min
   - Diagnostic Test: Quality of Life
      - Subject will complete Quality of Life Questionnaire

[/instrument] Many observational studies and some randomized controlled trials use a crossover design to evaluate exposure-response relationships. A crossover study is an example of an observational study that incorporates an intervention. Many crossover studies also randomize subjects to different treatment groups at a single time point, so they have elements of a cross-over, parallel-group randomized controlled trial. You can use the "Split-plot" tool to create this type of design.
There may be some cases where you want to compare the efficacy of two treatments using a within-subject design where each subject is their own control or where each subject receives both treatments. To do this, you can use the "Crossover" tool and set the entry into the within-subject factor as the treatment of interest and the exit from the factor as the control or contrast treatment. The default setting for the within-subject factor is 2x2 but you can change it to suit your needs. Then, just choose a block size that will provide an adequate number of treatment-control pairs.
For example, we could use a 2x2 within-subject crossover design with a block size of 2 to compare two treatments: 1) treatment #1: drug A, and 2) treatment #2: no treatment.
When the same subject is given both treatments, some factors need to be fixed and other factors are randomized. The fixed factors are the subject and treatment factors since every subject receives both treatments. The random factors would be the blocks and within-subject factors; in this case, the treatment-control crossover.
